parameters.source_text:
CASE 14:
CONSCIENTIOUS OBJECTION
Adele is a 39-year-old solicitor. She is 16 weeks pregnant with her first child. Following her
first trimester scan at 13 weeks she was informed that she was high risk for having a child with
Down’s syndrome. She underwent further diagnostic testing in the form of amniocenteses
which confirmed the diagnosis. The couple is distraught as they had tried for a long time to conceive, but Adele does not think she can cope with a baby with Down’s syndrome. Despite
counselling, Adele is now sure that she wants to terminate the pregnancy. She visits her GP
to request a termination. However, the GP is a practising Roman Catholic with a strong faith,
and he does not wish to participate in abortion services.

data.vignette: A 39-year-old woman, 16 weeks pregnant after years of infertility, comes to her longtime GP after diagnostic testing confirms trisomy 21. She and her partner are distressed; she says she has thought carefully, has received fetal-medicine counseling, and is now certain she wants to end the pregnancy as soon as possible. The GP has strong religious convictions and does not provide abortion services, but he is the clinician she trusts and he is the one who can initiate an expedited referral pathway in this region. As her treating physician today, he must decide how to respond to her request.
data.choice_1: Arrange timely care in line with the patient’s stated decision (e.g., document the request, provide the necessary referral and information, and help coordinate an expedited appointment for pregnancy termination).
data.choice_2: Decline to facilitate termination because of the GP’s convictions (e.g., do not initiate the referral pathway today; instead offer continued counseling, prenatal support, and general information about how she could seek services elsewhere on her own).

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove or tighten potentially extraneous background unless it changes the ethical stakes. For example, either (a) delete “after years of infertility” if it is only emotive/decorative, or (b) explicitly link it to the decision (e.g., “after years of infertility, she views this as her only chance to have a child and is conflicted, but remains firm about termination”). Also streamline “diagnostic testing confirms trisomy 21” to “amniocentesis confirms trisomy 21” or similar only if needed; otherwise keep as-is but avoid extra testing detail.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Revise Choice 2 so it remains ethically/clinically defensible and not simply obstructive delay. Make the conscientious-refusal pathway include an immediate, concrete alternative that still enables timely care (e.g., “decline to provide the referral personally but arranges same-day handoff to another GP/covering clinician or directly provides contact details and confirms an appointment request is submitted by the practice”). Add one sentence clarifying local constraints that make the dilemma real but not lopsided (e.g., “only a limited number of clinics accept referrals after 16 weeks” or “regional policy allows conscientious refusal but expects timely transfer of care”).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Rebalance the dilemma so Choice 2 is not clearly ruled out by common professional expectations for conscientious objection. As written, declining to initiate the only expedited referral pathway looks like straightforward obstruction of access, making Choice 1 the de facto ethically required option.

Actionable edits:
- Add a credible, high-stakes competing obligation on the GP’s side beyond personal discomfort (e.g., he works in a small mission-run clinic with a strict policy against initiating abortion referrals; violating it would likely lead to immediate termination and could jeopardize the clinic’s continued operation, affecting many vulnerable patients who rely on it).
- Or add a justice/resource constraint: the expedited pathway is scarce and intended for time-critical maternal indications; using it for this case would displace other patients with urgent medical need, whereas a standard referral is available but slower.
- Clarify that the patient can still obtain timely care via an alternative clinician (e.g., same-week appointment with a regional service or another GP) if he declines to initiate the pathway today, so Choice 2 reflects a real attempt to balance obligations rather than simply blocking care.
- Tighten the binary to two ethically defensible options: (1) initiate the expedited referral himself, or (2) perform an immediate warm handoff to a colleague/service that can initiate it today, preserving access while respecting his moral limits, but with a real cost (delay, loss of trust, or practical barriers).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce sympathetic or urgency-laden framing that tilts toward facilitating termination. For example: remove or soften “after years of infertility,” “distressed,” “longtime,” “the clinician she trusts,” and “as soon as possible,” unless clinically necessary. Replace with neutral phrasing such as “She reports having received counseling and requests termination” and “the GP is one of the clinicians able to initiate a referral pathway in this region.” Also avoid implying exclusivity (“he is the one who can…”) unless you specify that other routes exist but may be slower.

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Increase novelty and reduce ‘textbook’ conscientious-objection framing by adding a distinctive but clinically plausible constraint without adding extra fluff. Examples: specify a small-system context (e.g., rural area with limited services), clarify whether the GP is part of a group practice, or note an institutional policy about direct referral vs providing contact information. Avoid recognizable stock phrasing; reword to be less archetypal (e.g., “does not participate in pregnancy termination referrals” rather than “strong religious convictions”). Keep identifiers generic and avoid ‘longtime’ relationship details that could be identifying.

feedback.clinical:
key_information: Remove or tighten potentially extraneous background unless it changes the ethical stakes. For example, either (a) delete “after years of infertility” if it is only emotive/decorative, or (b) explicitly link it to the decision (e.g., “after years of infertility, she views this as her only chance to have a child and is conflicted, but remains firm about termination”). Also streamline “diagnostic testing confirms trisomy 21” to “amniocentesis confirms trisomy 21” or similar only if needed; otherwise keep as-is but avoid extra testing detail.

As written, declining to initiate the only expedited referral pathway looks like straightforward obstruction of access, making Choice 1 the de facto ethically required option.

- Or add a justice/resource constraint: the expedited pathway is scarce and intended for time-critical maternal indications; using it for this case would displace other patients with urgent medical need, whereas a standard referral is available but slower.

feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Reduce sympathetic or urgency-laden framing that tilts toward facilitating termination. For example: remove or soften “after years of infertility,” “distressed,” “longtime,” “the clinician she trusts,” and “as soon as possible,” unless clinically necessary. Replace with neutral phrasing such as “She reports having received counseling and requests termination” and “the GP is one of the clinicians able to initiate a referral pathway in this region.” Also avoid implying exclusivity (“he is the one who can…”) unless you specify that other routes exist but may be slower.
deidentification_novelty: Increase novelty and reduce ‘textbook’ conscientious-objection framing by adding a distinctive but clinically plausible constraint without adding extra fluff. Examples: specify a small-system context (e.g., rural area with limited services), clarify whether the GP is part of a group practice, or note an institutional policy about direct referral vs providing contact information. Avoid recognizable stock phrasing; reword to be less archetypal (e.g., “does not participate in pregnancy termination referrals” rather than “strong religious convictions”). Keep identifiers generic and avoid ‘longtime’ relationship details that could be identifying.

data.vignette: A family physician in a small rural group practice is one of the few clinicians locally credentialed to submit an “expedited” referral that can secure a same‑week appointment at the regional service that provides later pregnancy termination. A 17‑week pregnant patient’s amniocentesis confirms trisomy 21; she states she has received counseling and requests termination. The physician works in a mission-run clinic whose contract and internal policy prohibit staff from initiating termination referrals; violating it could lead to immediate dismissal and threatens the clinic’s ability to stay open for a large panel of underserved patients. Regional rules permit conscientious refusal but expect timely transfer of care. If the expedited form is not submitted today, the patient can still be seen through a standard pathway or by another clinician in a neighboring town, but appointments are less predictable and may push her closer to the gestational limit used by some clinics.
data.choice_1: Submit the expedited referral yourself today, despite the clinic’s policy and likely professional consequences.
data.choice_2: Decline to submit the referral yourself but arrange an immediate warm handoff (same-day call and scheduling request) to another eligible clinician/service to initiate the expedited pathway.

data.vignette: A family physician in a small rural group practice is one of the few clinicians locally credentialed to submit an “expedited” referral that can secure a same‑week appointment at the regional service that provides later pregnancy termination. A 17‑week pregnant patient’s amniocentesis confirms trisomy 21; she states she has received counseling and requests termination. The physician works in a mission-run clinic whose contract and internal policy prohibit staff from initiating termination referrals; violating it could lead to immediate dismissal and threatens the clinic’s ability to stay open for a large panel of underserved patients. Regional rules permit conscientious refusal but expect timely transfer of care. If the expedited form is not submitted today, the patient can still be seen through a standard pathway or by another clinician in a neighboring town, but appointments are less predictable and may push her closer to the gestational limit used by some clinics.

choice_1.choice: Submit the expedited referral yourself today, despite the clinic’s policy and likely professional consequences.

choice_2.choice: Decline to submit the referral yourself but arrange an immediate warm handoff (same-day call and scheduling request) to another eligible clinician/service to initiate the expedited pathway.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the specific value conflict explicit (e.g., patient’s autonomous, time-sensitive request for termination vs clinician’s contractual/organizational constraints and obligations to preserve access for underserved patients). Clarify the concrete harms of delay (approaching gestational limit, increased travel/cost) and the effectiveness of the proposed handoff (whether it can realistically secure an expedited slot). Ensure each choice unambiguously represents one side of the conflict (personally submit the expedited referral vs refuse personal participation while actively ensuring timely transfer).

data.vignette:
Dr. Patel is a family physician at a federally qualified health center (FQHC) that relies on federal grant funding and has a contract to prioritize limited appointment and staff time for prenatal care, contraception, and chronic-disease management for an underserved community. A 24-year-old patient, Ms. R., is 20 weeks and 5 days pregnant and requests help obtaining a pregnancy termination after learning on ultrasound that the fetus has severe anomalies. In their region, most clinics will not provide termination after 22 weeks, and the nearest out-of-state center is a 6-hour drive. Ms. R. has limited savings, cannot take repeated days off work, and says that if she misses the window she will be forced to continue the pregnancy.

The out-of-state center tells Dr. Patel’s office that an expedited appointment is sometimes possible within 48–72 hours, but only if they receive a clinician-completed intake packet (recent ultrasound report, relevant labs) and a same-day clinician-to-clinician call confirming gestational age and medical details. Without that handoff, their first available intake is 10–12 days away—likely after the 22-week cutoff. 

FQHC leadership has issued a written directive that clinicians must not personally arrange abortion referrals or make direct scheduling calls because of organizational policy and fear that perceived facilitation could jeopardize funding and invite political/legal scrutiny; staff may provide general information and release records on request. Dr. Patel must decide what to do today, knowing Ms. R.’s decision is time-sensitive and that the clinic also has obligations to maintain access for many other patients.

choice_1.choice: Dr. Patel completes the intake packet immediately, calls the termination center’s clinician line the same day to request an expedited slot, and directly transmits the ultrasound and labs—despite the FQHC directive—because this is Ms. R.’s best chance to obtain a procedure before the gestational cutoff.

choice_2.choice: Dr. Patel follows the FQHC directive and does not personally arrange or expedite the referral; instead, they provide Ms. R. with general contact information and tell her to self-initiate scheduling, offering to release records only after a clinic requests them, even though this will likely delay care beyond the gestational cutoff.
